articles.headline: A Bid to Park Recalled G.M. Cars Is Denied
articles.snippet: A federal judge denied a motion that would have forced General Motors to advise the owners of the 2.6 million recalled cars to keep them off the road until they are fixed.
articles.abstract: A federal judge denied a motion that would have forced General Motors to advise the owners of the 2.6 million recalled cars to keep them off the road until they are fixed.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors may be losing the public relations battle in its recall of defective cars, but the company scored a victory on Thursday in its escalating legal war.

articles.headline: Enrollments Exceed Obama’s Target for Health Care Act
articles.snippet: Eight million people have signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, including what the White House said were a sufficient number of young, healthy adults needed to maintain the plan’s viability.
articles.abstract: Eight million people have signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, including what the White House said were a sufficient number of young, healthy adults needed to maintain the plan’s viability.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Thursday that eight million people have signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, including what the White House said were a sufficient number of young, healthy adults, a critical milestone that might counter election-year attacks by Republicans on the law’s success and viability.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Health Law Bellwether, UnitedHealth Posts Lower Profit
articles.snippet: Profit declined 7.8 percent partly because of the health law and the high costs of a hepatitis C treatment.
articles.abstract: Profit declined 7.8 percent partly because of the health law and the high costs of a hepatitis C treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, reported lower earnings on Thursday, attributing its weak results in part to the federal health care law.

articles.headline: Merely Rich and Superrich: The Tax Gap Is Narrowing
articles.snippet: The wealthy face tax increases that are greater for investment income, much of which goes to the superrich.
articles.abstract: The wealthy face tax increases that are greater for investment income, much of which goes to the superrich.
articles.lead_paragraph: Will this be the year that the superrich finally pay higher taxes than the very rich?

articles.headline: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs Adjust to New Banking Climate
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley’s solid first quarter provides evidence that it has adapted better to a stricter regulatory environment than rivals like Goldman Sachs, which reported an earnings decline.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley’s solid first quarter provides evidence that it has adapted better to a stricter regulatory environment than rivals like Goldman Sachs, which reported an earnings decline.
articles.lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs had not reported earnings on the same day since the darkest phase of the financial crisis in 2008, but they did so again on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Hollywood Begs for a Tax Break in Some States, Including California
articles.snippet: A battle for filmmaking tax credits has begun in several states — including in California, the home of Hollywood — and has led to cutbacks in others like Maryland.
articles.abstract: A battle for filmmaking tax credits has begun in several states — including in California, the home of Hollywood — and has led to cutbacks in others like Maryland.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The San Fernando Valley has served as home to award-winning movies like “E.T.,” “Boogie Nights” and “Crash.” But Raul Bocanegra, a state lawmaker representing a large swath of the valley, worries about the collapse of film and television production in his district and across Hollywood’s home state.

articles.headline: Lucrative Stardom in China, Using a Webcam and a Voice
articles.snippet: Companies across the globe have long tried to attract viewers to live Internet broadcasts, with X-rated sites the only real success stories. China appears to have cracked the code.
articles.abstract: Companies across the globe have long tried to attract viewers to live Internet broadcasts, with X-rated sites the only real success stories. China appears to have cracked the code.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZIGONG, China — Dolled up with makeup and a blond wig, the pretty young Chinese woman sat at home in her bedroom on a quiet Sunday evening and began singing karaoke.

articles.headline: Deal is Reached to Ease Tension in East Ukraine
articles.snippet: The United States, Russia, Ukraine and the European Union reached an agreement on Thursday that called for armed pro-Russian bands to surrender the government buildings they have seized.
articles.abstract: The United States, Russia, Ukraine and the European Union reached an agreement on Thursday that called for armed pro-Russian bands to surrender the government buildings they have seized.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United States, Russia, Ukraine and the European Union reached an agreement on Thursday evening that called for armed pro-Russian bands in eastern Ukraine to surrender the government buildings they have seized and that outlined other steps to defuse a crisis that has rattled the international community.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Cost of Treatment May Influence Doctors
articles.snippet: Some of the most influential medical groups in the nation are recommending that doctors weigh the costs, not just the effectiveness of treatments that they recommend for patients.
articles.abstract: Some of the most influential medical groups in the nation are recommending that doctors weigh the costs, not just the effectiveness of treatments that they recommend for patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saying they can no longer ignore the rising prices of health care, some of the most influential medical groups in the nation are recommending that doctors weigh the costs, not just the effectiveness of treatments, as they make decisions about patient care.

articles.headline: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everest’s Risks
articles.snippet: An avalanche that left at least 12 dead has focused attention on the Sherpas, skilled high-altitude climbers who put themselves at great risk for the foreign teams that pay them.
articles.abstract: An avalanche that left at least 12 dead has focused attention on the Sherpas, skilled high-altitude climbers who put themselves at great risk for the foreign teams that pay them.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Sherpas always go first, edging up the deadly flank of Everest while international clients wait for days in the base camp below.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: A Hidden Art Trove and a Lost Relative
articles.snippet: A new exhibition in Germany focuses on the work of Cornelia Gurlitt, an Expressionist artist who was also the sister of a Nazi-era art dealer whose trove of masterpieces was recently seized in Munich.
articles.abstract: A new exhibition in Germany focuses on the work of Cornelia Gurlitt, an Expressionist artist who was also the sister of a Nazi-era art dealer whose trove of masterpieces was recently seized in Munich.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOCHSTADT, Germany — Last November, Hubert Portz was at his home in Hochstadt, southwest of Mannheim, reading a story in the morning newspaper when he came across a familiar name, causing his heart to skip a beat.

articles.headline: Pro-Russian Insurgents Balk at Terms of Pact in Ukraine
articles.snippet: A U.S.-backed deal to settle the crisis in eastern Ukraine fell flat but appeared to arrest, at least temporarily, the momentum of separatist unrest in the region.
articles.abstract: A U.S.-backed deal to settle the crisis in eastern Ukraine fell flat but appeared to arrest, at least temporarily, the momentum of separatist unrest in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — An American-backed deal to settle the crisis in eastern Ukraine fell flat on Friday as pro-Russian militants vowed to stay in occupied government buildings, dashing hopes of a swift end to an insurgency that the authorities in Kiev portray as a Kremlin-orchestrated effort to put Ukraine’s industrial heartland under Russian control.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Andrew E. Kramer
